Award.AwardTitle: SusCHEM: Supramolecular Assembly and Catalysis Applications of Organoborane Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Frieder Jaekle of the Department of Chemistry at Rutgers University-Newark is studying a new class of polymers that contain the element, boron. Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life that utilize plastics, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. In this research project, Professor Jaekle is developing methods to synthesize polymers that contain specific boron-containing groups and then to utilize these polymers as catalysts for chemical reactions. Major features of these catalysts are that they are stable and easily recycled for further use. Professor Jaekle is training a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students in a highly interdisciplinary research environment. The students are using and maintaining instrumentation for polymer research and education at Rutgers University-Newark. Professor Jaekle and his group are also involved in K-12 outreach activities and the stimulation of international scientific exchange through the organization of international symposia.

Organoboranes are well-known for their Lewis acidic properties. When combined with hindered Lewis bases so-called "frustrated Lewis pairs" are generated that can be exploited in small molecule activation and in various catalytic processes. There are few examples of recyclable versions of these high-value catalysts, though. Professor Jaekle is studying how to attach functional organoboranes to both soluble polymers and polymer resins with easily accessible functional groups. Two target structures are being pursued: (1) highly electron-deficient triarylboranes that in concert with Lewis bases are capable of activating small molecules such as dihydrogen or silanes: These polymers will be tested as catalysts in the hydrogenation and hydrosilylation of imines, aldehydes and ketones. (2) electron-deficient borinic acids and corresponding polymers that are expected to display unusual self-assembly characteristics through hydrogen bonding and Lewis acid-base interactions: These polymers will be tested as catalysts in amidation reactions. Outreach activities involving K-12 students are being planned, including the participation of high school students from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds in research through the ACS Project SEED and the organization of Polymer and Materials Chemistry Outreach Programs that involve local schools with predominantly minority students.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project new methods have been developed for the attachment of borane Lewis acid groups to polyolefins and the replacement of CC units in polyolefins with isosteric BN units. The incorporation of boron into polymers offers opportunities for development of "smart" materials and recyclable catalysts that facilitate chemical transformations. The use of boron, rather than metal species, is appealing as a potentially more sustainable approach in these applications. In catalysis, the attachment of boranes to polymers offers advantages in terms of recycling of the precious active ingredients. Using boron-containing polymers, we also invented a new class of elastomeric materials that can be thermally reprocessed. The results have been published in 5 original research articles and included in over 50 presentations to audiences in the US and oversees.

The grant enabled the training of 1 postdoctoral researcher, 3 graduate students, and 4 undergraduate students. Many of these students came from groups that are underrepresented in the field of chemistry. They were trained in scientific methods such as multinuclear NMR, GC-MS, MALDI-MS, handling of air-sensitive compounds, monomer synthesis and purification, and in polymerization techniques. They were also mentored in respect to scientific writing and presentation skills and offered opportunities to present their work at conferences.

Serving the broader scientific community, the PI coedited a book on "Main Group Strategies towards Functional Hybrid Materials" and, together with a postdoctoral associate, completed a review on "Functional Polymeric Materials Based on Main Group Elements". These works are expected to serve as valuable resources for researchers in the field. In addition, the PI organized the 10th US-Japan workshop on "Advances in Organic/Inorganic Hybrid Materials" that was held at Rutgers University-Newark from June 17-21, 2018, bringing together researchers from academia, national laboratories, and industries from the participating countries. Finally, personnel involved in this project played an integral part in the management and maintenance of a multi-user polymer and nanomaterials characterization facility at Rutgers University-Newark (PolyRUN).

The PI's group participated annually in outreach programs with high school students from the Newark Public Schools. We also organized a materials chemistry outreach program for about 45 high school students who had an opportunity to experience current research efforts in materials chemistry first-hand, while learning about college applications, curricula, and opportunities for financial support. The PI also hosted 4 high school summer students in his labs, including two minority students from disadvantaged backgrounds through the American Chemical Society Project SEED.


Last Modified: 11/03/2019
Modified by: Frieder Jaekle
